How does evolution happen when mutations do not and can not create new body parts? Evolutionists need a mechanism of random change that links new body parts to a vehicle of inheritance. But they don't have it.
 
 Let's take for example the hypothetical evolution of a millipede. Evolutionists say that this creature evolved from a primitive worm. However, a worm has no legs. Thus, some sort of mechanism would have to come along to create all these legs. But mutations don't add new body parts, and that's because mere changes in matter cannot add the information needed to create them. What's needed to add new body parts is an entirely new/different developmental pathway -- but mutations don't create those either, they only make them defective, resulting in defects, duplications and disease.
 
 And it's not just millipedes evolving from worms. Evolutionists say snails spiders, lobsters and squids also evolved from a worm. But these other creatures have antennaes, gills, glands that emit poison, compound eyes, etc and many more structures that worms don't have. Not only that but even if a worm were to create one of these body parts, it would not turn them into a completely different creature (A millipeded is not a mere worm with legs.); it would simply create a worm who posesses that particular trait. 
 
 And it's the same the world over. There are millions of new parts for evolutionists to account for. Another example is the bat's sonar system. Assuming that the earth's most primitive organism (some sort of bacteria-like creature) did not have sonar capabilities, at some point this capability had to evolve by way of the evolution of new physical hardware. But how? (Of course, this says nothing of the reality that other bats would have to be able to receive and interpret this new sonar-producing capability, which would also require the evolution of new hardware....randomly, of course.)
 
 So how does the evolution of new body parts happen? -- and yes -- since this is science -- I would like some scientific evidence, including some examples of mutations that create new parts.
 
 Without a mechanism for the production of new body parts, we can assume that an organism that contains entirely new or different parts cannot be evolved from another organism that lacks them.

 Bats use their sonar as echo-location, not as a means of communication with others, don't they?

 sonar is more than that; it's a method of communication.
 
 http://dsc.discovery.com/news/briefs/20041025/bat.html
 
 Whenever females heard sonar sounds from another female, they would call less frequently, likely to tune in to what the other female was communicating. According to the researchers, female bats interact mainly with other females in complex hierarchies during their lives, so that could be why they take more of an interest in echolocation sounds from their own sex.
 
 .....She told Discovery News, "The connection of the two studies is in the idea that bat communication is more complex than previously documented, since research is finding a variety of social calls to be communicating territory defense and mate attraction, as well as sonar calls, previously thought to only function in prey capture and navigation, to also have a communication role."
This is essentially the "I don't understand how it could happen so godmustadunit" argument.

How does evolution happen when mutations do not and can not create new body parts? Evolutionists need a mechanism of random change that links new body parts to a vehicle of inheritance. But they don't have it.
 Actually random mutation combined with selection and inheritance is all thats needed. The stochastic tajectory of a linage on the fitness landscape will result in "body parts" which change over time. If you think otherwise you are rowing along without a paddle. For example suppose we take a bacterium which has no body part which will chew up lactam based antibiotics. All it takes is a point mutation of a active and existing protease (which itself evloved) to a slightly different substrate specificity and tada you have a new "body partt". All one need do is to elaborate this kind of thing to more complex multigenic traits and off ya go - parts galore from microbes to complex multicellular critters like apes and man. A whole set of different stochastic tajectories and linages operating on the fitness landscape for billions and millions of years. The mechanism is quite adequate to produce what you can observe in nature today.

Let's take for example the hypothetical evolution of a millipede. Evolutionists say that this creature evolved from a primitive worm. However, a worm has no legs.
 As I have pointed out elsewhere marine worms DO have appendages and millipedes do not have "legs". They have appendages but they are not legs. Look at the name. Its not millipod, its millipede. Pod refers to limbs, Pede referers to feet - and in this case not the kind of feet that tetrapods have either. The appendages of millipedes are analogous to the appendages on marine worms, although they are more elaborated.
 
 The whole "body parts" deal is a McGuffin you have cooked up to support your argument. At the very least you should get your facts straight if you are going to do this sort of trick.

But mutations don't add new body parts, and that's because mere changes in matter cannot add the information needed to create them.

 What is so sacred about this type of "information" that it cannot be produced randomly?
 
Of course, this says nothing of the reality that other bats would have to be able to receive and interpret this new sonar-producing capability, which would also require the evolution of new hardware....randomly, of course.

 The words "reality" and "have to" should never have been added to that sentence.
 
 The reality is, bats could have evolved echolocation as a navigating tool, and learned to apply it to hunting and communication later. After all, all three uses require the same "hardware": an organ to generate the sonar, and an organ to receive it.

Without a mechanism for the production of new body parts, we can assume that an organism that contains entirely new or different parts cannot be evolved from another organism that lacks them.
 Indeed, however variation, selection, inheritance as postulated in standard evolutionary theory provides the relevant mechanism. And of course without a mechanism one can never get from here to there, but thats not relevant to a claim that neo-Larmarckism IS the mechanism involved. Especially not in the face of data to the contrary.
 
 One has to bear in mind that Behe makes (badly) the same argument in order to invoke "irreducible complexity" followed by invocation of a "designer" or "creator". His argments are holier than thou and are totally flawed. Its an argument from ignorance - GOD of the gaps. And its invalid.

But mutations do produce new chemical structures (and chemical structures ARE physical structures!). For example a point mutaion of A to T due to a copy error or a chemical mutaion or an inversion or a number of other factors results in a NEW physical structure namely a sequence of DNA which is different than its predecessor. Such structures are active not passive and the subsequent chain of causation can and does produce "new" physical structures given sufficient numbers of mutations accumulated over time. You can ignore the evidence for this as you have done so far, but the evidence remains and the conclusions of science remain. And you might consider the evolution of the HOX gene family itself, which appears to have arisen by duplication and subsequent divergence. Its a long way from Amphioxus to mammals!
 ==========================
 
 
 [Hox genes, developmental evolution and the origin of vertebrates]
 
 [Article in Russian]
 
 Holland RW, García-Fernández J.
 
 School of Animal and Microbial Sciences, University of Reading, Whiteknights, UK.
 
 Homeobox genes comprise a diverse multigene family encoding transcription factors, many of which are key control genes in early development. The roles of several homeobox gene subfamilies have been widely conserved through animal evolution, but there are detailed differences in homeobox gene number, genomic organisation and gene expression between taxa. We have compared Hox and other homebox genes between vertebrates and their closest living relatives, Amphioxus. The results suggest that after evolutionary divergence of these two lineages, homeobox and other genes were duplicated in the lineage leading to vertebrates, but that Amphioxus retained the archetypal homeobox gene organisation. We suggest that prior to vertebrate origins there was an intense phase of gene duplication, followed by recruitment of new developmental control genes to new roles. These genetic changes may have permitted the evolution of novel developmental and anatomical characters, and the origin of vertebrates.

Science 29 September 2006:
 Vol. 313. no. 5795, pp. 1918 - 1922
 DOI: 10.1126/science.1132040
 
 Prev | Table of Contents | Next
 Review
 Genomic Evolution of Hox Gene Clusters
 Derek Lemons and William McGinnis
 
 The family of Hox genes, which number 4 to 48 per genome depending on the animal, control morphologies on the main body axis of nearly all metazoans. The conventional wisdom is that Hox genes are arranged in chromosomal clusters in colinear order with their expression patterns on the body axis. However, recent evidence has shown that Hox gene clusters are fragmented, reduced, or expanded in many animals-findings that correlate with interesting morphological changes in evolution. Hox gene clusters also contain many noncoding RNAs, such as intergenic regulatory transcripts and evolutionarily conserved microRNAs, some of whose developmental functions have recently been explored.
 
 cience 27 November 1998:
 Vol. 282. no. 5394, pp. 1711 - 1714
 DOI: 10.1126/science.282.5394.1711
 
 Prev | Table of Contents | Next
 Reports
 
 Zebrafish hox Clusters and Vertebrate Genome Evolution
 
 Angel Amores, Allan Force, Yi-Lin Yan, Lucille Joly, Chris Amemiya, Andreas Fritz, Robert K. Ho, James Langeland, Victoria Prince, Yan-Ling Wang, Monte Westerfield, Marc Ekker, * John H. Postlethwait *dagger
 
 HOX genes specify cell fate in the anterior-posterior axis of animal embryos. Invertebrate chordates have one HOX cluster, but mammals have four, suggesting that cluster duplication facilitated the evolution of vertebrate body plans. This report shows that zebrafish have seven hox clusters. Phylogenetic analysis and genetic mapping suggest a chromosome doubling event, probably by whole genome duplication, after the divergence of ray-finned and lobe-finned fishes but before the teleost radiation. Thus, teleosts, the most species-rich group of vertebrates, appear to have more copies of these developmental regulatory genes than do mammals, despite less complexity in the anterior-posterior axis.
 
 Science 27 November 1998:
 Vol. 282. no. 5394, p. 1609
 DOI: 10.1126/science.282.5394.1609r
 
 Prev | Table of Contents | Next
 This Week in Science
 The hox genes, which are so critical for pattern specification during development, are aligned in clusters on the chromosomes. Although lower chordates have only one cluster, tetrapods have four, and, as now shown by Amores et al., (p. 1711) zebrafish have seven. The additional clusters likely arose early in the evolution of fishes, perhaps by whole genome duplication, and may have provided the tools to support the diversification of fishes.
 
 Originally published in Science Express on 6 May 2004
 Science 28 May 2004:
 Vol. 304. no. 5675, pp. 1335 - 1337
 DOI: 10.1126/science.1091946
 
 Prev | Table of Contents | Next
 Reports
 Origins of Bilateral Symmetry: Hox and Dpp Expression in a Sea Anemone
 John R. Finnerty,1* Kevin Pang,2 Pat Burton,1 Dave Paulson,2 Mark Q. Martindale2
 
 Over 99% of modern animals are members of the evolutionary lineage Bilateria. The evolutionary success of Bilateria is credited partly to the origin of bilateral symmetry. Although animals of the phylum Cnidaria are not within the Bilateria, some representatives, such as the sea anemone Nematostella vectensis, exhibit bilateral symmetry. We show that Nematostella uses homologous genes to achieve bilateral symmetry: Multiple Hox genes are expressed in a staggered fashion along its primary body axis, and the transforming growth factor-ß gene decapentaplegic (dpp) is expressed in an asymmetric fashion about its secondary body axis. These data suggest that bilateral symmetry arose before the evolutionary split of Cnidaria and Bilateria.
 
 Originally published in Science Express on 1 June 2006
 Science 7 July 2006:
 Vol. 313. no. 5783, pp. 63 - 68
 DOI: 10.1126/science.1128650
 
 Prev | Table of Contents | Next
 Research Articles
 Hox Control of Organ Size by Regulation of Morphogen Production and Mobility
 Michael A. Crickmore1 and Richard S. Mann2*
 
 Selector genes modify developmental pathways to sculpt animal body parts. Although body parts differ in size, the ways in which selector genes create size differences are unknown. We have studied how the Drosophila Hox gene Ultrabithorax (Ubx) limits the size of the haltere, which, by the end of larval development, has ~fivefold fewer cells than the wing. We find that Ubx controls haltere size by restricting both the transcription and the mobility of the morphogen Decapentaplegic (Dpp). Ubx restricts Dpp's distribution in the haltere by increasing the amounts of the Dpp receptor, thickveins. Because morphogens control tissue growth in many contexts, these findings provide a potentially general mechanism for how selector genes modify organ sizes.

what's needed to create a new structure is a new developmental genetic pathway -- and mutations don't create those.
 
 Actually they do. Do have any evidence to the contrary? Namely that developmental pathways do not undergo mutation?  gene duplication does not create new genes, at least not genes that lead to common descent.....if it did, the following should be true: First, there should be a large number of nonfunctional duplicated genes in genomes. Second, if individual genes are going to be duplicated, then also duplicated would be large sequences or blocks in the genome. This would infer that the genome would be quite messy and not particularly well-organized or proficient in regard to function. The absence of these duplicated sequences and the highly streamlined, productive genome makes it obvious that evolution did not happen by way of gene duplication.
 
 Not only that, but in order to be selected, these newly-duplicated genes must be somehow expressed, which means it must translate into some useful body part. But if all these thousands of random gene duplications actually happened and then got expressed, why is it that we see no oddballs or chaotic phenotypes in the animal world or in the fossil record? Not only that, but these individually duplicated genes would have to translate to a whole, functional body part in order to be selected. But individual genes don't translate to whole body parts; in fact, body parts are not translated individual genes; genes work in groups and are merely tools used by the body to express itself...and these expressions can vary depending on enviornmental circumstances.

 oh?
 
 By whatever means, if evolution of new genes has to be achieved by tinkering with randomly duplicated genes by random mutations within the duplicated genes, on statistical basis we should see many, many more duplicated genes undergoing such evolution than we see today in the genomes of living organisms. Again, if sequences are being overwritten, the inability of incipient genes (a partially new gene in the process of formation of a fully new gene) being selected would show that it is extremely improbable to evolve new genes if unselected genes are being overwritten. Under such circumstances, it is simply improbable to evolve a new gene by tinkering with a duplicated gene within the short time-frame in which the distinct organisms are said to have evolved. 
 
 The reality is that the set of genes of any organism is essentially constant. A genome is changed by the many types of mutations including point mutation and gene-duplication, but only to change the intergenic junk sequences and introns to a great extent. Even the protein coding exons can mutate up to about 90% without changing the structure or the function of the proteins they encode (due to the high tolerance of every protein to amino acid sequence variation) -- all without evolving new genes or new organisms. This physical genetic-flux -- occurring independently in distinct, independently originated organisms -- is mistakenly cited as the molecular mechanism of evolution, but the evidence simply does not support that conclusion. These genetic changes are the cause for the normal "individual variations" in the population of an organism. As I mentioned before, any other genetic change would only lead to a defective organism, not to a new organism.

The reality is that the set of genes of any organism is essentially constant.
 Of course it is. Why would it not be? But evolution does not occur for individuals, it occurs when genes within a population change due to variation and selection. And one of the mutations is a change in the number of copies of a given gene. Indeed this happens in humans from time to time when chromosomes go missing or extra ones show up. Usually this has no effect that is favorable to survival/reproduction (trisomy can cause disease). But look at plants where polyploids often have big showy flowers which in an environment containing gardenrs tend to improve reproductive success. Most polyploids of course don't survive, certain ones do.
 
 The fact of life is that duplications do happen, can be observed, and are well known. If you want a few hundred citations let me know.

why is it that we see no oddballs or chaotic phenotypes in the animal world 
 But of course we do see odd balls don't we. Rather often in fact. Even in humans. Try superfemales and Klienfelters syndrome. Try sickle cell trait, try polydactaly, try snakes with two heads, try albino buffalo or crocs!!!!

I missinterpreted "green revolution" I thought had something to do with the irrelevence of the Green party due to their blowing of the 2000 Presidential race.
 Then you are an idiot and poorly educated about the culture you live in.
 Check WIKI:
 Green Revolution
 From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
 (Redirected from Green revolution)
 Jump to: navigation, searchThe Green Revolution is a term used to describe the transformation of agriculture in many developing nations that led to significant increases in agricultural production between the 1940s and 1960s. This transformation occurred as the result of programs of agricultural research, extension, and infrastructural development, instigated and largely funded by the Rockefeller Foundation, along with the Ford Foundation and other major agencies.
 
 J. George Harrar, who would later become president of the Rockefeller Foundation, headed the Office of Special Studies. Its lead scientists included Norman Borlaug, Edwin Wellhausen, and William Colwell. Researchers from both the United States and Mexico were involved in this program. The main initiative of the Office was the development of high-yielding maize and wheat varieties. Borlaug received the 1970 Nobel Peace Prize for his work on wheat breeding.

The problem is evolutionists know what would happen: as soon as they stick a population of animals in a new environment, they and their ancestors would all start giving birth to offspring who were some how adapted (or adapting) to the environment.
Really? Please explain. How can it be that if I introduce some specimens into a new environment, that their ancestors, that have not been subjected to that new environment (and in fact, are most likely dead) produce offspring that are adapted to an environment into which their descendants were introduced. I just can't conceive of any mechanism by which an ancestor can be influenced to produce offspring that are influenced by offspring that have been removed to new environment. How can the new environment into which the progeny have been introduced have any effect on the parents, who continue in the old environment. Please explain how that works.

 Actually natural selection was recognized long before Darwin, its consequences were however not imagined. Nobody with their eyes open would not notice that some variants of a species were more likely to survive and reporduce than others. Even primitive hunters and gathers likely noticed this. There is really not a lot to test after all.  natural selection, the way darwinists explain it, says much more than the fit will survive: it says selection creates the fit....and the way it does this is by selecting the fit (which go on to reproduce better) from a pool of fit and unfit variants. 
 
 "The essence of Darwinism lies in a single phrase: Natural selection is the creative force of evolutionary change. No one denies that selection will play a negative role in eliminating the unfit. Darwinian theories require that it create the fit as well." - Stephen J. Gould, The Return of Hopeful Monsters, Natural History vol 86, June/July 1977, p 28
 
 Ultimately, I argue that the NS can't create fitness because fitness is created from within each creature....and if the whole population emerges fit from the developmental process, reproduction becomes more of a lottery of who's in the right place at the right time -- along with some sexual selection thrown in.

I do not argue that the fit are most likely to survive and/or breed -- I argue that the NS can't create fitness because fitness is created from within each creature.
 Fitness is diue to genetic composition of an individual. NS sets the criiteria as to what is fitter. There is no creation in the process at all. Just VSI.

Ok nutballs....
 
 I've asked you guys for any evidence that mutations can create a new, functional body part. I was given no such evidence. Mutations may be able to inflict harm on an organism, resulting in defects such as a duplication of an already-existing body part or a rearrangement of an already-existing body part such as a leg sticking out of the head of a fly, but as far as generating new morphological characters the well is bone dry.
 
 check out the following quote from Biochemist Ernst Chain, who shared a Nobel Prize for his work on Penicillin:
 
 To postulate, as the positivists of the end of the last century and their followers here have done, that the development and survival of the fittest is entirely (his emphasis) a consequence of chance mutations, or even that nature carries out experiments by trial and error through mutations in order to create living systems better fitted to survive, seems to me a hypothesis based on non evidence and irreconcilable with the facts....These classical evolutionary theories are a gross oversimplification of an immensely complex and intricate mass of facts, and it amazes me that they were swallowed so uncritically and readily, and for such a long time by so many scientists without a murmur of protest.
 
 So my question is this: I don't know if anything could convince you that mutations do not perform as advertised -- that they do not create new, beneficial body parts such as limbs, organs or any other tissues -- but if something could convince you of this, how would you, how could you, continue to cling to your theory without them? How could you still possibly believe in common descent without mutations and without a mechanism to create new body parts? 
 
 ToE was based on the premise of natural selection culling random mutations. Without random mutations to cull, natural selection has no materialistic mechanism of heredity to select. Therefore what you'd be left with is nonrandom variation plus nonrandom natural selection....and there's nothing random or materialistic about that.
 
 So to repeat my question: could you still believe in common descent without random mutations in the mix? If so, how?.....please explain how common descent could happen without them....
 
 And just in case you doubt the importance of mutations to ToE, check this out from Futuyma:
 
 http://www.actionbioscience.org/evolution/futuyma.html
 
 There cannot be evolution without genetic variation in the first place. So there must be mutation and often recombination to generate the different genotypes or the different versions of the genes, known as alleles, which then may or may not make a difference in the ability of an organism to survive and reproduce. You can't have any evolutionary change whatever without mutation, and perhaps recombination, giving rise to genetic variation
 
 Lynn Margulis:
 
 
 The major difference between our view and the standard neodarwinist doctrine today concerns the importance of random mutation in evolution. We believe random mutation is wildly overemphasized as a source of hereditary variation....Many ways to induce mutation are known but none lead to new organisms. Mutation accumulation does not lead to new species or even to new organs or new tissues. Acquiring Genomes. Pg. 15
 
 
 The neodarwinists' inventive literature and valiant attempts to unite the genetic stability in the unblended mixture of Gregor Mendel's factors to the gradual evolutionary change promoted by Darwin's natural selection were as brilliant as they were incorrect. Pg. 201
 
 by the way, I'm having to work alot lately so if I don't get back quickly, just hang tight and be patient.

So my question is this: I don't know if anything could convince you that mutations do not perform as advertised -- that they do not create new, beneficial body parts such as limbs, organs or any other tissues -- but if something could convince you of this, how would you, how could you, continue to cling to your theory without them? How could you still possibly believe in common descent without mutations and without a mechanism to create new body parts? 
 The question is moot since mutations can and do occurr and since morphology is changed when they do so. All thats necessary is to change morphology over billiions of years. Doing so generates ultimately modifications which appear to be "new". Flagella from secretory mechanisms, Proteins greatly changed in shape from their starting points, formation of simple photosensors from pigmented cells, and subsequent modification of same into various forms of eyes - including our own, transformation of fins to limbs, transformation of earlier structures to fins, formation of those earlier structures from sheets of cells, etc etc etc. Frankly your idea of "new" body parts meaning de novo from no precursors is absurd. There are no "new" body parts all arose ultimately by modification via heritable variations. I would challenge you to name a "new" body part and we can start from there. Find me one which did not arise from some form of precursor structure!

And here its time to introduce just how "body parts" are produced in the first place. For most diploid species it all starts as a fertilized egg or its equivalent which subsequently divides, folds up in various ways and grows differentially to produce the "body part s" its a morphing into the final form (thus morphology). The parts are produced during this process and the sequencing and specifics are the controlling facttors of what one ends up with be it a frog, a mouse, or a man. The details and dynamics are largely determined by the specific genome along with all its integral control elements and master switches. Alter that system by mutation and potentially the body parts which result are also altered. Add a new component by duplication and suAbsequent mutation and you get a different result yet again. In a very real sense there are no "body parts" only elaborations of structure generated by the geneome during development. The so called developmental program. And that program is mutable.

There is a theory about all this. (I just formulated it). Lets call it Allens Law.
 
 All body parts are derived by modification of previously existing body parts. Parts are used to make "new" parts once you have even a single part.

so from what did a bat's sonar come from? How did legs appear on a millipede from a worm? Are you honestly telling me that all morphological characters stem not from newly-arising parts, but from modifications of a bacteria-like creature? Are you serious? Bacteria doesn't have legs or sonar or hair or bones or wings or tongues or flippers or kidneys or kidney cells ---- how did this stuff modify from a bacteria?...and by way of mutation, no less.

Are you honestly telling me all morphological characters stem from modifications of a bacteria-like creature? 
 Well in theory yes, provided that bacteria like critters are near the earliest common ancestor. Where else do you think it would come from EVEN under your own theory of evolution? Where did the bacterial flagellum come from? Well by modifiction of existing "parts". You might ask M. Behe how his argument to the contrary went. Where did the first life-forms come from - well by modifications of prior chemical systems which were non-livin?g. Even if GODdunit and made em from clay! How many different structures can you build from bricks or modifications of bricks????? How many organic compounds can you make from C,H,O,N in combinations? How many possible life forms can DNA specifiy? All of morphology comes from previously existing morphology with modification and descent. This is one of the beautifual and aweinspiring things about evolution. Today a fin, tomorrow (well next 10 million years) a limb. Today a limb, tomorrow a hand, or a hoof, or a clawed paw etc.

Are you serious? Bacteria doesn't have legs or sonar or hair or bones or wings or tongues or flippers or kidneys or kidney cells ---- how did this stuff modify from a bacteria?...and by way of mutation, no less.
 Of course not, but they do have precursors to precursors to precursors ......... going back n generations of precursors. You should never forget the pure power of selection applied to the cumulated variability of life over billions of years. Lots of time to make the parts to make the parts to make the parts to make the parts......Plenty of time to do a drunkards walk through fitness space with trillions of different drunkards (each corresponding to a linage) and indeed to branch off trillions of new linages.

so from what did a bat's sonar come from?

 
 From pre-existing ears and larynx. Where else do you think they came from? Your deity zapped them into existence with an "Abracadabra!" and a wave of his magic wand?
 
 
How did legs appear on a millipede from a worm?

 
 From breathing appendages that could, to some extent, assist in locomotion. What is so hard about that? And yes, chemist is right. Many marine worms have segmental appendages that assist in breathing and locomotion, but are not bona fide legs. Nereis, for example.
 
 
Are you honestly telling me that all morphological characters stem not from newly-arising parts, but from modifications of a bacteria-like creature?

 
 No, we aren't telling you anything so stupid. That is your straw man, constructed from a total inability to understand evolutionary theory.
 
 
 Are you serious?

 
 We are serious about the theory. You are serious about making up straw men.
 
 
 Bacteria doesn't have legs or sonar or hair or bones or wings or tongues or flippers or kidneys or kidney cells ---- how did this stuff modify from a bacteria?...and by way of mutation, no less.

 
 It didn't. Not directly, anyway, only through a long series of intermediates, many of which are known. Why do you foolishly claim anyone said they sprung directly from bacteria?
 
 A prerequisite to discussing evolutionary theory is a basic understanding of it. You just don't have it. That's why trying to teach you anything really interesting about is a complete waste of time. You just aren't interested in anything except attacking straw men of your own construction that have no relevance to reality.

The other one I've heard about is this: animals with different ancestors cannot have identical body parts, if they do evolution is canned. Most cases this is true, but one part keeps coming back: the beak. The beak is apparent in birds, platypuses, cephalopods, and some cetaceans. Obviously since these animals have the same body part, they must be proof of design right?
 
 Wrong.
 
 Marine animals naturally acquire beaks or beak-like mouths (seen more often in ancient tetrapods), because it is easier to catch the thousands of micro-organisms that way (as well as larger animal that may escape mid-chew). This would mean that over time, animals with jaws will acquire beaks.
 
 This doesn't explain birds. Actually it does - most birds (if not all) come from a common ancestor which lived near the ocean - it would have to go in the water often to get food (as seen in some arctic and antarctic birds). Not only that, but the air offers the same zero-gravity environment as the ocean, making a beak just as viable as it would be in the water.
 
 Any questions? Ask.
